newsitem.title: GHANA: Ghana presidential rival a seasoned politician.
newsitem.headline: Ghana presidential rival a seasoned politician.

text.p: John Agyekum Kufuor, the main challenger to Ghana's president Jerry Rawlings in presidential elections on Saturday is a seasoned politician and businessman.
Kufuor, who will be 58 on Sunday, is a lawyer by training who sat in parliament and served briefly as a minister under Rawlings in 1982.
He has few good things to say about his former boss, who was then a young military ruler.
"The regime started committing brutalities. I wrote Rawlings that I disagreed and resigned," Kufuor told Reuters on Thursday. "The murder of three magistrates was for me the main reason to resign."
Kufuor's father was the Oyokohene of Kumasi, the head of the clan of the powerful king of the Ashantis.
Educated at Oxford, England, Kufuor boasts an impressive track record in business which he holds as a his main credential for seeking to take charge and transform Ghana's economy.
"The people of Ghana know that if anybody is going to stabilise Ghana and will make private enterprise flourish, it is Kufuor," he said.

"Right from the beginning when he took power...Rawlings has made life impossible for business people. His U-turn from Marxism to capitalism...for a long time only favoured multinationals, not the native business community," he said.

"Only two years ago Ghanaian businessmen began breathing a bit freer. But take gold mining, a major growth sector, there are hardly Ghanaian entrepreneurs involved. This government has always frightened off private initiative," he said.

"Rawlings kept calling businessmen thieves, crooks, for a long time and confiscated important companies, such as a brewery and a salt industry. The Ghanaian business community can never trust him," he said.
The New Patriotic Party (NPP) and the People's Convention Party (PCP), against the odds, formed an alliance in August, and chose NPP's Kufuor as a joint candidate.
Although there is a third candidate, surgeon Edward Mahama of the People's National Convention, most pundits agree the race is between Rawlings and Kufuor -- and it's likely to be close.
Kufuor's party, which won almost a third of the vote in 1992, groups the professional classes with moderate conservative tradition.
The PCP, which did not exist in 1992, follows the socialist line promoted by Kwame NKrumah, Ghana's first president.
Born on December 8, 1938, Kufuor is married to Theresa Aba Mensah, a nurse. They have five children.
